job_title: Medical Assistant in Roseville, CA
pros: The medical benefits provided is the only viable "pro" for kaiser
cons:
*Threatened all non vaccinated employees termination if they would not comply -- allowed for "medical" exemptions but these exemptions are ONLY if you have an allergic reaction to a dose, underlying health problems? doesn't matter.
*Provided assistance for employees during covid via daycare stipends -- the organization approved these requests week by week and money was paid. After the fact they made mistakes and demanded lumpsum repayments further just hurting employees. 
*Middle management is paid based on their ability to save money -- this means that open positions are not filled timely adding to workload of employees.
*Union is in the corporations pocket, only validates concerns when inline with organizations beliefs not contractual agreement.
*Company policies are not enforced at all levels, raising concern only brings reprisal through denied vacation requests (despite coverage), additional duties, and general workplace hostility.
*Seniority poisons the well of workers -- as seniority increases odds of termination decrease causing a lazy workforce of experienced individuals.

job_title: Senior Consulting Associate in Oakland, CA
pros: Great healthcare benefits and a pension plan still exists.
cons: I think this varies widely by department, but it seems that colleagues will step on one another to get ahead.  My male colleagues would advocate for me and champion my ideas, but my female colleagues would talk over me or embarrass me in front of internal clients whenever possible.  My female boss who was older by at least a decade(who has since returned to the company after being managed out) took me aside to let me know that letting my naturally wavy, ethnic hair be wavy was unprofessional and I needed to straighten it.  She also put me on notice that I needed to wear more makeup under the guise of “helping” me.  She took credit for work that was well-received but wouldn’t hesitate to throw various team members (including me) under the bus if the work didn’t meet the client’s needs due to her misdirection.  There definitely was an “in” group of white women, and as a woman of color I certainly wasn’t allowed in.  I’ve since left the company and haven’t encountered this type of mean girls culture elsewhere.  Thank goodness most other employers have more collaborative, supportive cultures for women of color.

job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Clinical staff and ancillary departments are generally kind and patient oriented. Knowledgeable physician and nursing teams.
cons:
Leadership and upper management is awful. Overall toxic environment where moving up is their priority instead of patient care. Do not work here if you are trying to make a difference. Los Angeles Kaiser is for people whose sole purpose is to move up and not improve health systems. Many people I’ve meet throughout the years have all shared similar negative experiences as POC when it comes to promotions and salaries. Maybe other KP locations are better, but if you are a POC I would recommend that you not work at KP Los Angeles. Look for another place that will treat you with respect and base performance evals on your work. Side note: several POC end up going on stress leave due to discrimination and working in toxic environments. 
Kaiser puts a lot of effort into “diverse hiring”, but puts no effort in ensuring staff are not discriminated against. They have this worthless HR compliance set up where they direct you to your leadership/managment for any complaints…does not help when your complaint is against your leadership/management.

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker in Washington, DC
pros: As a therapist, it is rare to find a site that offers a regular salary and full benefits. The pay is very good, and there is a union that protects me from being wrongly fired. My salary increases every year, and I have free medical care.
cons: Where do I begin? The senior management is horrible. There is little to no concern for the well-being of employees, and although they speak of work/life balance, they do everything possible to ensure that there is none. There is never enough staff. We are required to have caseloads of hundreds of patients, and we are expected to have at least 1/3 of our weekly appointments be new intakes. When a patient has an intake, they can expect their next appointment to be in 2-3 months. It is impossible to provide the care that our patients need. Managers tend to be short-sighted and they micromanage our cases, very inappropriately. There are ridiculous metrics that we are expected to meet, most of which have nothing to do with providing the care that the patient needs. There is very little autonomy for therapists, and the managers who do well there (who don’t leave after 6 months) are ones who are autocratic and narcissistic. This is a workplace that allows me to make decent money, for the mere price of my soul.

job_title: Senior Manager in Oakland, CA
pros:
Colleagues are very nice, and collaborative. Rare to encounter someone who is totally an obstacle.
Health benefits are good (but if mental healthcare really matters to you, I have heard from many that access to care is insufficient, trying to work on it but I've known people who get mental healthcare outside of KP even though they are members)
cons:
Lots of decisions make you question leadership at KP - and maybe the decisions are fine but then leadership is not communicating well.
It would be good if they were open to hiring more leaders from the outside, to inject new ways of thinking, a market perspective. 
It feels like being a cog in a big machine - which can be good or bad depending on how you view your career - it is a good place for people who want a job, paycheck, work toward a pension, with nice colleagues who believe in Kaiser's mission. People who are really driven to make change, can get frustrated or I worry get trained to start thinking this is just how Kaiser is or does it.

job_title: Senior Instructional Designer in Denver, CO
pros: The work/life balance is like no other company I've ever worked for. The emphasis on taking care of your health is very strong and a priority over your job. I've never had that work environment before where you can take a PTO day and not feel guilt or anxiety. The benefits are wonderful, better than other employers I've had. I'm not scared going bankrupt by going to the doctor, the insurance is that great.
cons:
Very poor work ethic as part of their work culture. "The bare minimum" or "only what's required" is the attitude I receive from most colleagues (not all). I've noticed the attitude is more prevalent in those whose career has only been KP (vs. people who have had a career prior to KP). Also, those who "grew up" in KP are grossly unaware of industry standards in their own field/job but think they're performing above those industry standards and "setting the KP standard". It's very disappointing if you have real-world experience and know just how far below standards/technology we actually are.

If you're an ambitious person wanting to grow your career, you could go very far at KP. It's difficult to get hired, but once you're in, your ambition and fire within can get your pretty far (pro/con: whether you're good at your job or not).

review_title: The Kaiser Model Does Not Favor the Physician.
job_title: Physician in Walnut Creek, CA
pros:
Health coverage for families.
The benefits, in general, are decent.
cons:
Kaiser might be an excellent fit for those providers directly out of training but only for a short period. You can most likely get a slightly smaller base salary out of the gate, and they sometimes offer sign-on bonuses/loans when they feel like it and to whom they think worthy but avoid taking this as they will undoubtedly ask for it back even if you move roles within Kaiser. I’ve seen this happen many times and see the same issues with the home loan. Back to the salary. The recruiting team will show you an expected salary after five years of service, reflecting a 5% increase each year. This is false and misleading. Even with the highest productivity with your group and very high patient satisfaction surveys, you will receive a generic letter in the mail thanking you for another year of dedication and a rate of increase less than 0.80% that feels more like a slap in the face. All the while, record inflation is rampant throughout the country at the same time when we live in the most expensive part of the country in California. 

To add insult to injury, during the pandemic, while we have been putting our lives on the line every day and putting our families at risk while Kaiser is making record profits of over $2 BILLION per quarter, they took away our overtime pay while on service. So, we step up, and they reduce our salary. Where is the fairness in that? We are certainly not treated like family at Kaiser like they love to tout. We are treated like third-rate expendable profit machines without the benefit of sharing the fruits of our 14-hour daily labors. 

The Kaiser model is not sustainable for the physician as you would be doing yourself a disservice in the long run for remaining at Kaiser. It might be feasible for two-three years max but less lucrative and tiring long term. There is no administration time while panel maximums are increased every time an intelligent physician leaves, and they decide not to backfill that position to save money. Everything at Kaiser ultimately comes down to profit and more ways to extract that profit from the physicians who give their lives for a system to take it away. 

There is an article titled why I left Kaiser that I recently came across with a quick internet search, and I recommend that you read it as well. A few of us are looking to start our own Reddit to share ongoing woes as they keep coming every way you turn the longer you stay at Kaiser.

cons: Expect a long bureaucratic process for every decision, idea, or general employee question. Because the benefits are good people tend to stay a long time and get stuck in always doing things the "kaiser way." Introducing new ideas or processes sounds great to managers in theory, but Kaiser operates with many levels of review so ideas often get stuck behind people who want to continue a process that has been in place for too long. Although tuition reimbursement and job growth is promoted the job recruitment system is outdated and you are unlikely to migrate into a new position without a direct connection.

job_title: Non-clinical Services Coordinator in Oakland, CA
pros:
+Great health benefits
+Stable company that has long history
+Well known and large in size
+Ahead of its competitors 
+Able to leverage technology 
+Able to adapt to changes
cons:
-Even when you're more competent, highly skilled and has great potentials, hiring managers will go with "experience and previous title on paper". Sadly, in KP it is not what you know, but who you know.

-KP can't assess talent and won't grow its new work force (less than 5 years of services at KP). They sometimes hire from the outside for people with the "right" experience. 

-Lack of training programs and opportunities for new work force (less than 5 years of services at KP)

-Horrible recruitment services. If you apply from the outside, you know how much of a black hole it is to apply on kp.org. It is not that much if you're a current employee applying to internal positions. Most KP recruiters are not helpful or friendly. 

-Pay raises are very little and are capped out at a certain percentage each year. 

-Each department is slow to make changes due to its large size and bureaucratic nature

-Lazy, and incompetent employees still allow to work, causing headaches for other dedicated, hard working, and competent employees.
